places.title: Dog Eared Books
places.description: I think this is my favorite book store, just from proximity to home. I like that a considerable amount of the store is dedicated to used books, and the recommendations are great to browse.

places.title: Sightglass
places.description: I like the pour-overs here. The beans here are light roast, if you're into making your own coffee.

places.title: Ritual
places.description: I like the cold brew here, but the pour over is also good.

places.title: I'a Poke
places.description: It's good poke. Embarassingly, I like the sushirittos the most.

places.title: Exploratorium
places.description: Go on thursday nights when it's adults only and drinks are served. The hands-on demos are fun to play with.

places.title: YamaSho
places.description: The spot for karaoke. I've never been to the restaurant on the ground floor.

places.title: Salumeria
places.description: I like the fried chicken sandwich. Jelle tells me that Salumeria is gone and this spot is now called *Flour + Water Pasta Shop*. Online, the menu still has the same fried chicken listed, so perhaps it was just a rebrand? YMMV.

places.title: Plow
places.description: Classic SF brunch. I don't know. It's pretty good? Try going during burning man to avoid a long wait.

places.title: Saint Frank Coffee
places.description: The coffee is good. I like the beans too. I would have come here more often if it weren't a bit out of the way.

places.title: Atlas Cafe
places.description: The coffee and food is fine. I like the relaxed vibe and that it's open late. On warmer days, the outdoor patio is very nice.

places.title: SFMOMA
places.description: This place is big. YMMV depending on what's on view. My favorite used to be the [Serra _Sequence_](https://www.sfmoma.org/watch/installation-richard-serras-sculpture-sequence/) in the sitting area, but it was removed circa Dec 2018.

places.title: Geta Sushi
places.description: This place is really solid for the price. The move is to just order a ton of nigiri.

places.title: Taiwan Bento
places.description: It's good Taiwanese bento. Simple flavors but really hits the spot. My favorite is the fried pork chop.

places.title: The Sweet Booth
places.description:
The most delicious taro smoothie you've ever had. I like it without boba.

I have gone countless times, but the proprieter (Calvin) does not seem to recognize me which makes me a little sad. Last time I went, it seemed like they were looking to sell the business, so window for experiencing this tier of taro smoothie may be closing.

places.title: YakiniQ Cafe
places.description:
I don't like the attached barbeque restaurant that much, but the cafe is good. The vibe kind of feels like a study cafe from a college town.

My favorite here is the yuzu honey tea, whether hot or cold.

places.title: Turtle Tower
places.description: The thing to get here is the pho ga. The chicken broth has a great umami flavor and reminds me of my mom's cooking from childhood.

places.title: House of Pancakes
places.description: Note the missing *International*. My favorites are the spicy fish, beef roll, and eggplant are my favorites. The pan-fried noodles and dumplings are also not bad.

places.title: Rintaro
places.description: Nice Izakaya. I like the vibe and the food is pretty good, though on the pricey side.

places.title: Garden Creamery
places.description: Great ice cream. Lots of interesting, rotating flavors. My favorites are the rice cake (for CNY), ube pandan, and matcha gold.

places.title: Stonemill Match
places.description:
The drinks and food are all good, though a little pricey. My go-to is the ochazuke and katsu sando. I'm not a big matcha fan, so my picks are the hojicha and sesame lattes.

On Sundays, they sometimes make Japanese milk bread which is by far my favorite. The baking schedule seems a bit irregular though, so it can be hard to get.

places.title: True Laurel
places.description: All of the cocktails are good. The snacks are great too. I like the fried mushrooms and the cookie.

places.title: Hinata
places.description: The sushi is very solid and great for the price. Would recommend calling and making sure you have a seat at the counter and not a table.

places.title: Sushi Hon
places.description: It's not bad, but less consistent than other places I've been to. I believe the owners also run Sushi Shio. Between the two, I like Shio more.

places.title: The Shota
places.description: My favorite place for omakase in the city. I like the tuna model that Chef Ingi sometimes shows off.

places.title: SaSa
places.description: Kaiseki that shares roots with Hinata. Everything's pretty solid, especially for the price.

places.title: bon, nene
places.description: French, Japanese fusion - this one's a hidden gem. My favorite here is the mentaiko pasta.

places.title: Daeho
places.description:
It's kalbijjim (korean shortrib stew). The wait can be long, but you can get in line on Yelp at opening and time your arrival.

I think the right order is the kalbijjim with cheese and veggies. The banchan is solid and I also like the kalbitang (soup).

places.title: Sushi Shio
places.description: The flavors here are on the less traditional, heavier side. I like salt (shio), so it's a good fit for me.
